The Grey Gas model is insufficient for understanding radiative forcing and feedback.
Phrase borrowed with great respect from

It’s time to move away from the Grey Gas approximation and look more carefully at the actual observed spectra of solar and terrestrial radiation.
The following figure shows observed spectra of solar radiation at
g with the theoretical Planck function for a blackbody at 5525 K.

This figure shows the solar radiation spectrum for direct light at both the top of the Earth’s atmosphere and at sea level. The sun produces light with a distribution similar to what would be expected from a 5525 K (5250 °C) blackbody, which is approximately the sun’s surface temperature. As light passes through the atmosphere, some is absorbed by gases with specific absorption bands. Additional light is redistributed by Raleigh scattering, which is responsible for the atmosphere’s blue color. These curves are based on the American Society for Testing and

terials (ASTM) Terrestrial Reference Spectra, which are standards adopted by the photovoltaics industry to ensure consistent test conditions and are similar to the light that could be expected in North America. Regions for ultraviolet, visible and infrared light are indicated.
The figure shows that that the incident beam at
has the shape of a blackbody radiator.
By the time the beam arrives at the surface, it is strongly depleted at specific wavelengths.

children.label: 5. Modeling spectral bands with the climlab.BandRCModel process

children.value: Here is a brief introduction to the
This is a model that divides the spectrum into 7 distinct bands: three shortwave and four
As we will see, the process works much like the familiar
The shortwave is divided into three channels:
Channel 0 is the Hartley and Huggins band (extreme
, 200 - 340 nm, 1% of total flux, strong ozone absorption)
Channel 1 is Chappuis band (450 - 800 nm, 27% of total flux, moderate ozone absorption)
Channel 2 is remaining radiation (72% of total flux, largely in the visible range, no ozone absorption)
